questions.question: A patient is brought to the trauma unit after being assaulted. He presents with severe pain, swelling, and deformity in the lower jaw. Imaging confirms a "bucket handle" fracture of the mandible. What is the most likely nerve to be injured in this type of fracture?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Inferior alveolar nerve Explanation: Inferior alveolar nerve runs through the mandibular canal and is at risk of injury in fractures of the mandible, especially those involving the body of the mandible, like butterfly fractures. Butterfly Fractures of the Mandible: Also Known As : "Bucket handle" fractures. Type : Bilateral body fractures of the mandible. Common Causes : High-energy impacts (e.g., motor vehicle accidents, assaults). Main Complication : Airway obstruction. Characteristics and Mechanism: Appearance : Fracture creates a "butterfly" pattern. Impact : Significant compromise of mandible’s structural integrity. Injury Mechanism : Involves high-force trauma, potentially leading to additional injuries in surrounding tissues. Diagnosis: Methods : Clinical Examination : Initial assessment. Imaging : X-rays, CT scans for detailed fracture evaluation. Management Strategies: Method Indication Details Closed Reduction Non-displaced or minimally displaced fractures Uses intermaxillary fixation (MMF) for stabilization. Open Reduction and Internal Fixation (ORIF) Displaced fractures Surgical realignment and stabilization using plates/screws. Complications: Malocclusion : Misalignment of teeth. Non-union : Failure of the fracture to heal properly. Nerve Injury : Particularly to the inferior alveolar nerve, causing altered sensation in the lower lip. (Option B) Lingual nerve (Option A ruled out) : This nerve is less likely to be injured in a mandibular body fracture as it is located more medially and higher up in the jaw. Hypoglossal nerve (Option C ruled out) : This nerve is involved in tongue movement and is not typically affected by mandible fractures. Facial nerve (Option D ruled out ) : The facial nerve controls facial muscles and is usually affected by fractures of the zygomatic arch or parotid area, not the mandible. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK553119/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8604616/

questions.question: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. On assessment, there is bruising around the left eye, and tenderness over the zygomatic arch. Which of the following imaging views is most appropriate for assessing a suspected zygomatic bone fracture?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Water's view Explanation: Water’s view plain film x-ray is preferred for evaluating zygomatic arch fractures. Investigations for zygomatic bone fracture: X-ray: water’s view (occipitomental view) is preferred CT scan- best investigation Treatment: Undisplaced fracture: Conservative management Displaced and symptomatic: Open reduction and internal fixation Caldwell's view (Option A ruled out) : (Occipitofrontal view) assessing fractures, and pathologies in the frontal and ethmoidal sinuses. Lateral skull view (Option C ruled out) : Non-angled lateral radiograph of the skull . Useful in basal skull fracture. Towne's view (Option D ruled out) : Useful for identifying fractures in the occipital bone.

questions.question: All of the following are true regarding the clinical presentation of zygomatic bone fracture except?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Deranged dental occlusion Explanation: Deranged dental occlusion is a manifestation of mandibular fracture. Zygomatic bone fracture: (tripod fracture) Fractures in 3 places: Zygomatico-frontal Zygomatico-temporal Infraorbital Clinical features: Swelling and bruising in the cheek. Flattening of the cheek (malar) prominence. (Option C ruled out) Step deformity of the infraorbital region. Epistaxis (Option A ruled out) Sensory loss in superior orbital nerve. Sensory loss in infraorbital nerve: upper lip, and alar region of the nose. (Option B ruled out) Enophthalmos is due to herniation of the orbital fat across the fracture floor of the orbit into the antrum. Diplopia- entrapment of the inferior rectus muscle restricting upward rotation of the eyeball while looking up. Infraorbital ecchymosis: Panda sign. Subcutaneous emphysema. questions.question: A 22-year-old male presents with pain in the jaw and difficulty opening his mouth after a fall from a bicycle, landing directly on his chin. On examination, there is tenderness at the left preauricular region with limited mouth opening. CT scan confirms an undisplaced fracture of the left mandibular condyle. The patient has no other injuries and is otherwise stable. What is the most appropriate management?

options.D: Surgical excision of the condylar head

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Intermaxillary fixation (IMF) Explanation: Most condylar fractures can be treated with closed reduction with intermaxillary fixation (IMF) and a strict soft diet and analgesic regimen. Investigation of mandibular fracture: X-ray of the mandible: Panoramic view Towne view CT head and face. Treatment: Restoration of dental occlusion is the foundation of mandibular fracture management. Condylar fracture: Closed reduction with IMF elastic guidance and a strict soft diet and analgesic regimen . (Option B ruled out) Displaced condylar neck fractures with significant loss of mandibular "font-size:11pt; font-variant:normal; white-space:pre-wrap"> ORIF techniques. (Option A ruled out) Displaced mandibular fractures: Antibiotics on admission followed by open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF). Severely comminuted fractures and difficult to fx with titanium plates: Intermaxillary fixation (IMF) with wires. Facial bones heal well after about 4 weeks. Surgical excision of the condylar head (Option D ruled out) : In condylar hyperplasia condition.

questions.question: A 24-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a motorcycle accident. He complains of severe pain in his lower jaw, difficulty closing his mouth properly, and numbness in his lower lip on the right side. Physical examination reveals swelling and tenderness over the right jaw, malocclusion, and a palpable step-off in the premolar region. The paresthesia in the patient’s lower lip is most likely due to the involvement of which nerve?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Inferior alveolar nerve Explanation: The inferior alveolar nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3), runs through the mandible and provides sensation to the lower teeth and lower lip. A fracture of the mandible can lead to compression or damage to this nerve, resulting in paresthesia in the lower lip. Mandibular fractures often present with several key clinical features, such as: Pain and tenderness: Especially over the site of the fracture. Malocclusion: A feeling that the teeth do not fit together properly due to misalignment of the fracture segments. Swelling and bruising: Over the area of the fracture. Step deformity: A palpable step-off along the jawline where the fracture has occurred. Paresthesia: Numbness or tingling in the lower lip and chin due to injury to the inferior alveolar nerve, which runs through the mandible. Facial nerve (Option A): primarily responsible for facial expression and not sensation in the lower lip. Mental nerve (Option C): a branch of the inferior alveolar nerve that only supplies the chin and lower lip externally. Isolated involvement of this nerve is uncommon in mandibular fractures. Lingual nerve (Option D ): provides sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, not the lower lip or jaw.

questions.question: A 3-month-old female infant presents with feeding difficulties and a noticeable facial deformity. On examination, the infant has a unilateral complete cleft involving the left lip, extending through the alveolus and hard palate, with an intact soft palate on the left side. The right side of the lip and palate are completely intact. What is the LAHSAL classification for this patient's cleft abnormality?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 00HSAL Explanation: Understanding LAHSAL Classification: LAHSAL is a system used to describe cleft lip and palate in a topographic and symmetrical manner, from the patient's right to left : Letter Meaning L Lip A Alveolus H Hard palate S Soft palate Capital letter Complete cleft Lowercase letter Incomplete cleft "0" Normal segment So: The first 3 letters (L-A-H) refer to the right side The last 3 letters (S-A-L) refer to the left side Breakdown of the Case: Left side : Lip cleft → L (complete, hence capital) Alveolus cleft → A Hard palate cleft → H Soft palate is intact → S = 0 Right side : Everything intact → L-A-H = 0-0-0 Putting this into LAHSAL: Right side (L-A-H) = 0-0-0 Left side (S-A-L) = H-A-L (from back to front) Final Code (Right to Left) = 00HSAL LAH000 (Option B): Incorrect, implies cleft on right side. LAHS00 (Option C): Incorrect, implies soft palate cleft on right and lip/alveolus normal. LAHSAL (Option D): Implies bilateral complete cleft (both sides involved).

questions.question: A mother brings her apparently normal 20-day-old newborn to the pediatric clinic with a complaint of milk coming through the nasal passages of the baby during feeding. Upon examination, you find the following: This condition is due to the failure of which of the following processes during embryonic development?

options.A: Fusion of the maxillary and medial nasal processes
options.B: Formation of the lateral palatine processes

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Fusion of the palatal shelves. Explanation: Cleft palate occurs when the palatal shelves fail to elevate and fuse properly during embryonic development, typically between the 6th and 9th weeks of gestation. This results in a gap in the palate, allowing communication between the oral and nasal cavities, as evidenced by milk coming through the nasal passages during feeding. Cleft palate: Defective fusion of the various components of the palate gives rise to clefts in the palate. Complete cleft palate: Bilateral complete cleft (A): Failure of fusion of both palatine processes of maxilla with premaxilla. A y-shaped cleft will be present between primary and secondary palate and between the two halves of secondary palate. It presents as a bilateral cleft of the upper lip also. questions.question: A 45-year-old male is diagnosed with a mandibular condyle fracture following an assault. The fracture is associated with malocclusion and facial asymmetry. Which of the following is a common post-surgical complication after open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) of this fracture?

options.B: Persistent pain and facial contour deformities

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Persistent pain and facial contour deformities Explanation: Mandibular condyle fracture following assault is known as Guardsman fracture. Post-surgical complications of ORIF for mandibular condyle fractures often include persistent pain, malocclusion, and facial contour deformities, particularly in cases with multiple fracture sites. Overview of Guardsman Fractures Definition : Guardsman fractures, also known as mandibular condyle fractures, result from trauma like assaults or accidents. Location : These fractures typically occur in the mandibular condyle, the rounded end of the mandible that connects with the temporal bone. Associated Injuries : Often associated with other mandibular fractures; approximately 50% of mandibular injuries involve multiple fracture sites, complicating treatment and recovery. Management Approaches Surgical Intervention : Common Method : Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) is the primary treatment to realign and stabilize the fractured segments. Incision Techniques : Retromandibular Incision : Provides access to the fracture site from behind the mandible. Preauricular Incision : Allows access in front of the ear, particularly useful for accessing the condyle. Surgical Tools : Bone clamps and lag screws are typically used during surgery to achieve proper reduction. Complications : Common Issues : Persistent pain, malocclusion (misalignment of teeth), and facial contour deformities. Risk Factors : The presence of multiple fractures increases the risk of complications, making precise surgical planning crucial. Temporomandibular joint ankylosis (Option A ruled out) : Although a possible complication of condyle fractures, it is less common than pain and facial deformities following ORIF. Complete loss of mandibular function (Option C ruled out) : This is not a typical complication; ORIF aims to restore function rather than cause complete loss. Intraoral hemorrhage (Option D ruled out) : While hemorrhage can occur during surgery, it is not a common post-surgical complication specific to ORIF of the mandibular condyle. Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11883964/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3324216/

questions.question: All of the following statements are true regarding the management of midface fractures, except?

options.A: Interdental or intermaxillary fixation is not mandatory

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Interdental or intermaxillary fixation is not mandatory Explanation: Interdental or intermaxillary fixation is mandatory in midface fracture Investigation of midface fracture: CT Treatment: Interdental or intermaxillary fixation is not mandatory (Option A) It is mandatory to: Reestablish the proper dentoskeletal relationship (Option B ruled out) Immobilize the fractured bone (Option C ruled out) Ensure normal postoperative occlusion (Option D ruled out) Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5423805/ https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/midface-fracture

questions.question: A 3-month-old infant presents to the pediatric clinic with feeding difficulties and nasal regurgitation. On examination, the infant has a cleft involving only the soft palate. There are no other abnormalities or syndromic features observed. When should surgery be planned for this infant with a cleft of only the soft palate?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) At 6 months Explanation: Surgery for a cleft of only the soft palate is ideally performed at around 6 months of age. This timing is crucial for optimal speech development and to minimize feeding difficulties, allowing the child to grow and develop normally. Management of cleft lip and cleft palate: Surgical principles: Cleft lip repair: reconnects the muscles around the oral sphincter. Cleft palate repair: anatomically closes the defect, facilitates speech development, minimizes maxillary growth difference and dentoalveolar deformities. Two-stage procedures may be used to minimize dissection. Secondary management (Post op): involves regular review by a multidisciplinary team for hearing, speech, dental development, and facial growth assessment. Surgical techniques: Cleft lip repair Cleft palate repair Millard rotation advancement technique( most widely used ) Bardach's Method Le Mesurier's Von Langenbeck Method (bipedicled) Thompson Wardill-Kilner Method/ V-Y plasty (unipedicled) Tennison-Randall Timing of Repair: Cleft lip Unilateral 5-6 months Bilateral 4-5 months Cleft palate Soft palate only 6 months Hard palate only 15-18 months Both soft and hard palate 2 staged Soft palate - 6 months Hard palate - 15-18 months Cleft lip and palate Unilateral 2 staged Cleft lip and soft palate - 5-6 months Hard palate - 15-18 months Bilateral 2 staged Cleft lip and soft palate - 4-5 months Hard palate - 15-18 months Reference: Bailey and love short practice of surgery, ed.28, page 745.

questions.question: A 2-day-old male infant is born with a unilateral cleft lip and palate. He is the first child of healthy, non-consanguineous parents with no significant family history. On physical examination, the infant has a noticeable cleft lip and palate. No other obvious abnormalities are noted. You suspect a syndromic association. Which of the following is the most common syndrome associated with cleft lip?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Van der Woude syndrome Explanation: Van der Woude syndrome is the most common syndrome associated with cleft lip and/or cleft palate. It is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by the presence of cleft lip, cleft palate, and lip pits. It is due to mutations in Interferon Regulatory Factor 6 [IRF6]. Other syndromes associated with cleft abnormalities: 1. Pierre Robin Sequence (Option B ruled out- not most common) 2. Treacher Collins Syndrome (Mandibulofacial Dysostosis) (Option C ruled out- not most common) 3. DiGeorge Syndrome (22q11.2 Deletion Syndrome) (Option D ruled out- not most common) 4. Apert Syndrome 5. Stickler Syndrome Reference: Bailey and Love short practice of surgery, ed. 28, page 741, 742. Langman’s medical embryology,ed.14, page 307.

questions.question: A 60-year-old patient is found to have a carotid body tumor that completely encases the carotid vessels, posing significant surgical challenges. According to the Shamblin classification system, what type of tumor does this describe?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Type III Explanation: Type III completely encases the carotid vessels, making surgical resection more challenging. CAROTID BODY TUMOR: Carotid body tumor Details Origin Chemoreceptor cells at the carotid body (carotid bifurcation) Associated Factors Chronic hypoxia (e.g., high-altitude exposure) Family history in ~10% Genetic mutations in SDH enzyme Pheochromocytoma Clinical Presentation Slow-growing, painless mass at carotid bifurcation Often pharyngeal mass Firm, rubbery, pulsatile, side-to-side mobility Bruit possible Avoid oral cavity biopsy for para pharyngeal swellings Usually benign; metastases are rare Diagnostic Tools Carotid Angiogram : Visualizes splayed bifurcation and outlines blood vessels MRI: Provides detailed anatomical information Contraindications: Biopsy and fine-needle aspiration (risk of bleeding) Shamblin Classification (Option D ruled out) Type I: Localized, <180° of carotid vessels (Option A ruled out) Type II: Encases >180° of carotid vessels (Option B ruled out) Type III: Completely encases carotid vessels, challenging to resect (Option C) Management Surgical: Careful in elderly; may require vessel reconstruction Alternative: Radiotherapy (not curative) Surgical Resection: For large tumors, may need vein autograft bypass to restore blood flow

questions.question: The intermaxillary segment gives rise to all of the following structures EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Secondary palate Explanation: The intermaxillary segment gives rise to the philtrum of the lip, four incisor teeth, and the primary palate. Development of the Lip and the Palate: The Lip: The upper lip is formed by the two medial nasal prominences and the two maxillary prominences. The lateral nasal prominences do not participate in formation of the upper lip. The lower lip and jaw form from the mandibular prominences that merge across the midline. The Palate: Intermaxillary Segment: Formation: Merging of the two medial nasal prominences, both at the surface and at a deeper level, due to the medial growth of the maxillary prominences. Components: Labial Component: Forms the philtrum of the upper lip. (Option A ruled out) Upper Jaw Component: Contains the four incisor teeth. (Option D ruled out) Palatal Component: Develops into the triangular primary palate. (Option B ruled out) Secondary Palate: Origin: The secondary palate is primarily formed by two shelflike outgrowths, known as palatine shelves, from the maxillary prominences. Fusion: The palatine shelves fuse anteriorly with the triangular primary palate. The incisive foramen serves as the midline landmark between the primary and secondary

questions.question: A 55-year-old male patient with squamous cell carcinoma of the oral cavity undergoes a right radical neck dissection. Three days postoperatively, the patient complains of shoulder weakness and difficulty in lifting his right arm above his shoulder. On physical examination, he has a limited range of motion in the right shoulder and exhibits winging of the scapula on the right side. What is the most likely nerve injured during the neck dissection that could explain this patient’s symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Accessory nerve (CN XI) Explanation: The accessory nerve (cranial nerve XI) innervates the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles. Injury to this nerve during a neck dissection can result in weakness of the trapezius muscle, leading to shoulder weakness , difficulty in lifting the arm above the shoulder , and winging of the scapula. Complications of Neck Dissection: 1. Nerve Injuries: Accessory nerve (CN XI) : (Option A) Shoulder weakness Difficulty lifting the arm above the shoulder Winging of the scapula Marginal mandibular nerve (branch of facial nerve): Asymmetrical smile due to drooping of the corner of the mouth Difficulty in controlling lower lip movements Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) : (Option D ruled out) Tongue deviation towards the injured side Difficulty in speech and swallowing Phrenic nerve: Diaphragmatic paralysis leading to respiratory difficulties (Option B ruled out) Vagus nerve (CN X): Hoarseness of voice Dysphagia Aspiration due to vocal cord paralysis Cervical sympathetic chain: (Option C ruled out) Horner’s syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis) 2. Vascular Complications: Hemorrhage: Hematoma: Chyle leak: Injury to the thoracic duct or lymphatic vessels Carotid artery rupture 3. Wound Complications: Infection Wound dehiscence Flap necrosis Seroma Reference: SRB’s Manual of Surgery, edition 6, page 441

This procedure is commonly used in cases with early-stage oral cavity cancers with limited nodal involvement and is known as supraomohyoid neck dissection. questions.question: Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured during surgery in the posterior triangle of the neck, potentially leading to weakness in shoulder elevation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Spinal Accessory Nerve (CN XI) Explanation: The Spinal Accessory Nerve (CN XI) is most likely to be injured during surgery in the Posterior Triangle of the neck. Injury to the spinal accessory nerve can lead to weakness in shoulder elevation and difficulty with scapular movements because the trapezius muscle is affected. The Hypoglossal Nerve (Option A ruled out) is found in the carotid triangle, primarily controlling tongue movements. The Vagus Nerve (Option B ruled out) runs within the carotid sheath in the carotid triangle. The Phrenic Nerve (Option C ruled out) runs along the anterior scalene muscle and is more associated with the lower neck and thoracic region, controlling the diaphragm. questions.question: Which of the following conditions is most commonly associated with a cervical rib?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Thoracic Outlet Syndrome Explanation: Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS) is the condition most commonly associated with a cervical rib. Definition : A cervical rib is an extra rib that arises from the seventh cervical vertebra (C7), located above the first rib. Cervical ribs can be present on one side (unilateral) or both sides (bilateral) of the body. Prevalence : It is a congenital anomaly present in about 0.5% to 1% of the population. Symptoms : Many individuals are asymptomatic. When symptoms occur, they may include neck pain, shoulder pain, or numbness/tingling in the arm and hand, supplied by segment T1. Symptoms arise due to compression of nearby structures such as nerves (e.g., brachial plexus) or blood vessels (e.g., subclavian artery), leading to conditions like Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS) (Option C) , common condition associated with a cervical rib, resulting from compression of neurovascular structures. Diagnosis : Typically diagnosed via imaging studies such as X-ray (neck). Treatment : Mild cases: Sling exercises. Severe cases: Scalenotomy (Resection of scalenus anterior muscles). Troublesome cases: Excision of cervical rib. Types of cervical rib: 1. Complete cervical rib: When it reaches up to the 1 cervical rib. 2. Bulbous end. 3. Tapering end. 4. Fibrous Band: If the end is replaced by a fibrous band. Rotator Cuff Tear (Option A ruled out) : Sometimes cause pain radiating down the arm, and shoulder movement is likely to be abnormal. There are no neurological symptoms . Not associated with cervical rib. Cervical spondylosis (Option B ruled out) : It is degenerative arthritis of the spine and rarely involves the T1 nerve root. Not associated with cervical rib. Pancoast’s syndrome (Option D ruled out) : It is apical carcinoma of the bronchus invading structures at the root of the neck causing pain, numbness and weakness of the hand. Not associated with cervical rib.

questions.question: Which branchial cleft remnant typically passes behind the carotid artery?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Third branchial cleft remnant Explanation: The third branchial cleft remnant typically passes behind the carotid artery, often traversing between the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves. First branchial cleft remnants (Option A ruled out) are typically found near the external auditory canal and do not pass behind the carotid artery. Second branchial cleft remnants (Option B ruled out) are commonly located along the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle but do not typically pass behind the carotid artery. Fourth branchial cleft remnants (Option D ruled out) are rarer and typically have a different course, often involving the lower neck and potentially the mediastinum, rather than passing behind the carotid artery.

questions.question: A branchial fistula typically presents with which of the following characteristics?

options.A: A midline neck mass that moves with swallowing
options.B: A lateral neck opening that drains mucus or saliva
options.C: A neck swelling that enlarges after a respiratory infection
options.D: A solid mass in the posterior triangle of the neck

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) A lateral neck opening that drains mucus or saliva Explanation: A branchial fistula typically presents as a small opening on the lateral aspect of the neck, often along the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. A branchial fistula is a congenital abnormality resulting from the incomplete obliteration of the branchial clefts or pouches during embryonic development. Origin : Typically arises from the second branchial cleft (most common), which fails to close properly. Anatomy : (Option B) The fistula is a complete ciliated columnar epithelium tract that connects the skin of the neck to the pharynx or tonsillar fossa. External Opening : Usually found along the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle in the lower third of the neck. Internal Opening : Typically located in the tonsillar fossa or near the pharyngeal wall. Clinical Presentation : May present with a small opening on the neck that drains mucus or saliva. (Option B) Can be associated with recurrent neck infections or abscesses. Swelling or discharge near the external opening is common. Diagnosis : Diagnosis is usually based on clinical examination. Imaging studies (e.g., ultrasound, fistulogram, or CT scan) may be used to delineate the fistula tract. Branchial sinus fistulography right side Treatment : Surgical excision of the entire fistula tract is the treatment of choice. Incomplete removal can lead to recurrence.

questions.question: A 38-year-old patient presents with a soft, translucent swelling on the front edge of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The swelling is non-tender and has not been associated with any infection. It is diagnosed as a branchial cyst. Which of the following is false regarding the given diagnosis?

options.A: Typical location is the meeting of upper and middle thirds of sternocleidomastoid.
options.B: It has an onset in late adulthood.
options.C: Cancerous lymph nodes may have to be ruled out.
options.D: Complete removal is done, ideally when not infected.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) It has an onset in late adulthood. Explanation: Branchial cysts typically present in early or middle adulthood. Branchial Cysts: Definition: Fluid-filled cysts from remnants of the second branchial cleft. Lined with squamous epithelium. Filled with thick, cloudy fluid. Appearance & Location: Typical Location: Front edge of the sternocleidomastoid muscle (where upper and middle thirds meet). (Option A ruled out) Onset: Early or middle adulthood. (Option B) Appearance: Soft, sometimes translucent swelling. Complications: Infection: May cause redness, tenderness, and difficulty in distinguishing from other neck masses. Age Consideration: In individuals over 35, rule out cancerous lymph nodes before surgical removal. (Option C ruled out) Treatment: Preferred Treatment: Complete removal, ideally when not infected. (Option D ruled out) Surgical Considerations: Cyst located above hypoglossal and glossopharyngeal nerves, but beneath the posterior belly of the digastric muscle. The spinal accessory nerve must also be identified to avoid damage.

questions.question: An infant presents with a translucent swelling in the neck that has been expanding over time as shown in the image below The swelling is filled with clear lymph and increases in size when the infant coughs.. Which of the following is false regarding the given condition?

options.A: Common locations include the cheek, axilla, groin, and mediastinum.
options.B: It has an unpredictable growth pattern.
options.C: It is incompressible and cystic in nature.
options.D: Injection of sclerosing agents can be given to reduce size.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) It is incompressible and cystic in nature. Explanation: The child is most likely suffering from Cystic hygroma , which is soft, partially compressible swelling filled with clear lymph. Features of Cystic Hygromas: Definition : Lymphatic malformations in neonates or infants. Appearance : Soft, partially compressible swellings filled with clear lymph. (Option C) Size Variation : May increase in size when the child cries or coughs. Common Locations : Neck (most common), face, submandibular region, tongue, floor of the mouth, cheek, axilla, groin, mediastinum . (Option A ruled out) Distinguishing Characteristics : Translucence. Behavior and Complications: Behavior : Unpredictable; can expand rapidly. (Option B ruled out) Complications : Respiratory difficulties (may require aspiration or tracheostomy). Risk of infection. Treatment: Preferred Treatment : Early complete surgical excision. Alternative Treatment : Injection of sclerosing agents to reduce size.
